candidates.title: Is This a Photograph of Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell in Donald Trump Campaign Shirts?
candidates.content:
Claim:
Actors Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell were spotted wearing Donald Trump campaign shirts.
Rating:
False
About this rating
In late April 2016, the above-reproduced image began circulating on social media, ostensibly showing actors Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell proudly sporting Donald Trump shirts.
At first glance, the photograph wasn't very convincing because of the contrast between the overlaid imagery and t-shirt fabric. It was fairly easy to prove the image was edited, as it first appeared in mid-2015 (without Trump details):
Even if the photograph's editing weren't so sloppy, the existence of the older original photograph gave the hoax away  it's incredibly unlikely paparazzi could have snapped identical (down to the facial expressions) images of Russell and Hawn in both mid-2015 and early 2016.
candidates.description: An image of actors Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell wearing Donald Trump campaign shirts is a digital fabrication.

result.explanation: The claim that actors Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell were spotted wearing Donald Trump campaign shirts is explicitly debunked by a fact-checking article from Snopes.com.  The article demonstrates that the image circulating online is a fabricated image and not a genuine photograph. Therefore, the caption is judged as false.
result.supporting_points: Snopes.com article: "An image of actors Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell wearing Donald Trump campaign shirts is a digital fabrication."

final_result.explanation: The internal check validates the caption based solely on the image content. It confirms the presence of Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell wearing shirts with Donald Trump's image and slogans. However, the external check, referencing a Snopes fact-check, decisively refutes the caption's claim. Snopes provides strong evidence that the image is digitally fabricated, meaning the depicted scenario never actually occurred.  The high confidence score (10) of the external check stems from the reputable source (Snopes) and their detailed explanation of the image's manipulation. This directly contradicts the internal check's assessment.  The conflict arises because the internal check analyzes only visual information within the image, without considering its authenticity. The external check, on the other hand, utilizes additional evidence (e.g., metadata analysis, reverse image search) to determine the image's legitimacy. This difference in methodology leads to the conflicting verdicts.  Entity analysis supports the external check.  While the image shows entities consistent with the caption (Goldie Hawn, Kurt Russell, Donald Trump imagery), the external check establishes that these entities are falsely represented within a fabricated context. Therefore, the external check's findings, supported by a reliable fact-checking source, override the purely visual analysis of the internal check.  The high confidence score reflects the strong evidence provided by Snopes, outweighing the internal check's visual confirmation.  The caption is deemed out-of-context because the presented image is a fake, and the events described never happened.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal check validates the image content but external check (Snopes) conclusively proves the image is fabricated. The external check's high confidence and reliable source override the internal check, indicating the caption is out-of-context.
